headline: Florida Supreme Court leaves Gov. Ron Desantis ' political map intact for 2022 elections
author: Doug Cunningham
sentences: The state Supreme Court's two-sentence statement declining to take the case said it was premature for justices to hear the case until it had moved fully through the state court system.
Black Voters Matter and other groups brought the suit over the maps, alleging that Black voters will see their ability to elect representatives of their choice diminished by the maps.
A statement on the Black Voters Matter website said the governor's political map is "a blatantly unconstitutional attack on Black representation in Florida."
June 2 (UPI) -- Florida's Supreme Court decided Thursday not to hear an appeal of a lower court decision on new congressional political maps.
Leon County Circuit Judge Layne Smith had issued a temporary injunction blocking the political redistricting plan.
The new maps ordered by DeSantis take apart a congressional district represented by Al Lawson, a Black Democrat.
The appeal court had thrown out a circuit court ruling to force redrawing of the congressional district maps.
The refusal to hear the case leaves in place a decision by Florida's 1st District Court of Appeal.
Ron DeSantis and passed by the GOP-controlled state Legislature will stand for the 2022 election.
The only other recourse for the groups who sued was the state Supreme Court.
He ruled the map was unconstitutional under the Fair District Amendment.
But his injunction was removed by the 1st District Court of Appeal.
That means the maps drawn by Gov.
